column1: Evanston is a city in and the county seat of Uinta County
column4: 359 at the 2010 census. It is located near the border with Utah.

column1: Evanston was named after James A. Evans
column2: a civil engineer for the Union Pacific Railroad. Another source maintains it is named for John Evans
column3: second Governor of the Territory of Colorado. The town was founded during the construction of the First Transcontinental Railroad.  The railroad arrived in the area in November 1868
column4: and Harvey Booth opened a saloon/restaurant in a tent near what is now Front Street.  By December the rails had reached Evanston and the first train arrived December 16. However
column5: orders were later handed down by the railroad managers to move the end of the line 12 miles west
column6: to Wasatch. Within three days most all of Evanston had moved to Wasatch
column7: it appeared that Evanston would become another "end of the tracks" town. Luckily
column8: in June 1869 headquarters returned to Evanston and it continued to grow. Later in 1871
column9: a machine shop and roundhouse were constructed
column10: giving Evanston a longevity not shared with many other railroad towns.Abundant timber and water along the Bear River made Evanston a refueling station for cross-country locomotives. Coal was mined a few miles north of Evanston in Almy.  Similar to other railroad towns in Wyoming
column11: early Evanston had a large population of Chinese railroad workers – in Evanston they lived on the north side of the railroad tracks in a small "China town."  Over time
column12: the Chinese population dwindled; the last two members of the first generation of immigrants died in the 1930s.Evanston was a major stop on the Lincoln Highway.  The highway ran east to west from East Service Rd to Bear River Dr
column13: on Front St to Harrison Dr
column14: to Wasatch Rd southwest to Echo Canyon in Utah. It can still be seen along Interstate 80
column15: which follows the railroad tracks in this area.

column1: Evanston underwent massive growth and change during an oil boom in the 1980s.  Recent drilling for natural gas has also revitalized the economy of the area. Union Tank Car works on railroad tank cars near the Union Pacific Railroad Complex
column2: locally referred to as the old roundhouse. and there are restored railroad buildings
column3: including a roundhouse in the downtown area.  One of the more recent restorations include 1011 Front Street where Michael's Bar & Grill currently stands. This restaurant is the oldest Bar & Grill in Evanston and once served as a store house for one of the first JCPenney stores in the country. This building
column5: is across the street from the museum in Depot Square.

column1: The Wyoming Department of Health Wyoming State Hospital
column3: is located in Evanston. The facility was operated by the Wyoming Board of Charities and Reform until that agency was dissolved as a result of a state constitutional amendment passed in November 1990.

column1: The United States Postal Service operates the Evanston Post Office.
